description:
Fusarium circinatum is a plant pathogenic fungus that is the causal agent of pitch canker disease in various pine species. It is a member of the Fusarium genus, which is known for its ability to infect a wide range of plant hosts.

Fusarium circinatum is a filamentous ascomycete fungus that produces three types of spores: macroconidia, microconidia, and chlamydospores. Macroconidia are the primary means of dispersal and infection, and they are typically sickle-shaped with several septa (cross-walls). Microconidia are smaller, single-celled spores that can also contribute to the spread of the pathogen. Chlamydospores are thick-walled, resting spores that can survive in the environment for extended periods.

The fungus infects pine trees through wounds, such as those caused by insect damage or pruning, and can colonize the inner bark and cambium, leading to the formation of resinous cankers. These cankers can cause dieback, top kill, and even mortality in affected trees. Fusarium circinatum is considered a serious threat to commercial pine plantations and natural pine forests, particularly in areas where it has been introduced outside of its native range.

Ongoing research is focused on understanding the biology and epidemiology of Fusarium circinatum, as well as developing effective management strategies to control the spread and impact of this devastating pine pathogen.
